postContent: #‚Äù 270 Seconds Later. One Qualified Injector Plate. One Step Closer to Orbit.  Last week, at the in Lampoldshausen, we wrapped up our third thrust chamber assembly ‚Äîand it delivered. @ & A total of 140 seconds of power.  & Same injection plate as in October ‚Äî reused for a total of 270 seconds of No degradation. Proof that our design not only works ‚Äî it lasts. And it's on track to be for our #S1B flight.  This chamber was designed and 100% in-house ‚Äî and thanks to our agile loop, each new version rolls out in under one month. That's the pace we've set ‚Äî and we're not slowing down.  Next stop? testing. And beyond that: qualification. To our ‚Äòteam ‚Äî your work is igniting more than just, It‚Äôs igniting the future of European capability. 3*  Thanks to and  for your support across our  Together, let's reach orbit.

Where Hardware Meets Purpose: The Journey of a Test Bench  Behind every successful engine test lies a powerful enabler: the Where theory meets reality and every subsystem is pushed to its limits.  * Over the past few months, our has been fully dedicated to the internal development and manufacturing of our first Sirius test bench. A major milestone for our company: we'll soon be testing and qualifying our on our own infrastructure, designed by Sirius, for  Our test benches are more than just infrastructure. They are strategic assets, custom- built to help us 7 and the critical components of, our faster and smarter. +  Thanks to our in-house design and software development, we've created flexible, robust platforms that allow us t  Accelerate test cycles Investigate issues in real time Hit our key technical milestones on schedule  & These test benches are the backbone of our toward engine qualification and, ultimately, flight.  From metal, code, and grit, we're building the path to space.  Together, let's reach orbit 3‚Äù

From 60 to 140 Seconds... And Beyond #‚Äù  Behind every iteration of our #combustionchamber, there's the work of an entire team, and a thousand decisions made along the way.  Each iteration brings us one step closer to our next goal: the qualification of a complete #engine.  From the first design sketches to hearing the chamber roar to life, each milestone is the result of the commitment and expertise of our #SpaceTeam. @  Our choice to internalize #inhouse the full chain, from #design to #manufacturing, is, what gives us the agility, precision, and expertise to push our #propulsion systems further with every test campaign.  Because every second counts and every second tells a story: Of ambition. Of hard work. Of resilience. |  Since 2023, our #testcampaign has grown steadily: 60 seconds at low thrust power - December 2023 120 seconds at full thrust power ‚Äî October 2024 140 seconds at full thrust power ‚Äî April 2025  And we're just getting started..  & Next up: a #fullengine test by the end of the year, and the first ballistic flight of #Sirius1 by the end of 2026.  From fire on the ground to flight to #orbit, the path to the stars is no longer a dream. It‚Äôs a timeline. We're proud of how far we've come and even prouder of the #SpaceTeam making it happen.  ¬© Special thanks to our #Propulsion and #Manufacturing teams for turning ambition into action, And to Centre National d'Etudes Spatiales and German Aerospace Center (DLR) for your support across our #Spacejourney  Curious to see what a combustion chamber looks like after 140 seconds at full thrust? Come meet us at our booth B2 during #SIAE25.

am ~'"lus Space Services 7 Follow fee 12301 Qwers c 3mo+¬Æ  Gearing up. Spinning up, and Pushing further! ¬©  On January 17, part of the Sirius Space Services team hit a key milestone in our #SpaceJourney.  At the German Aerospace Center (DLR) test bench in Lampoldshausen, our in- house #Turbopump successfully completed its first #testcampaign.  In just 12 seconds, it ramped up to 45,000 rpm, proving its ability to deliver high- pressure liquid methane (LNG) under real flight conditions‚Äîincluding bearings and the same sealing system as in our engine.  {| Fun fact - The red glow in the video comes from gaseous hydrogen burning to power the turbines. However, in the final version of our engine, we will use methane from the regenerative circuit of our expander cycle.  GB Next steps - We are finalizing the analysis of test data and moving fast toward the LOx turbopump, one of the most critical components of the engine.  This crucial milestone is paving the way for full-scale STAR-1 #FullEngine tests, as every test brings us closer to orbit!  A big shout-out to our Turbopump Department team for their hard work and dedication, and a special thanks to our partner, German Aerospace Center (DLR), for their invaluable collaboration in making this test campaign a success!  Together, let's reach the orbit! sf

[News]-' Major Space Launch Mileston  irius Space Services Partners with Equatorial Launch Austre  (ELA) for a  We're thrilled to announce an exciting new chapter for Sirius Space Services in collaboration with Equatorial Launch Australia (ELA)! This partnership is set to elevate our space launch capabilities to new heights.  @ Key Milestone: Sirius Space Services has secured a significant multi-year, multi- launch agreement with ELA to operate from the Arnhem Space Centre (ASC) in Australia. This pivotal partnership will see us become a ‚ÄúResident Launcher‚Äù at ASC, marking our entry into a new phase of our space journey.  {| Why This is a Game-Changer ?  ‚Äò* Expanded Orbital Access: Our new partnership allows us to offer a wide range of orbital inclinations, including medium and low orbits in SSO, LEO, and equatorial, enhancing our mission capabilities.  + Full-Service Excellence: Beyond launch services, we provide a comprehensive, integrated solution that includes not only the design and engineering of our rockets but also complete mission management.  * Strengthened Collaboration: This milestone highlights the robust and forward- thinking collaboration between Sirius Space Services and ELA, boosting our global operational prowess.  ¬∞% What's on the Horizon?  * Innovative Launch Infrastructure: Sirius Space Services will leverage ELA‚Äôs advanced ASCALP‚Ñ¢ launch pad design, tailored specifically to our needs. This integration will enhance the efficiency and safety of our launches, marking a significant advancement in our operational capabilities.  * Launch Timeline: The SIRIUS campaign will kick off with the ballistic flight of Sirius 1, scheduled for 2026 in Australia, followed by the launch of the Sirius 13 launcher (800 kg payload capacity) in 2027, paving the way for high-frequency commercial orbital missions.
